title: Selma Blair reveals she is 'doing well' as she continues to battle multiple sclerosis
text:
Selma Blair has revealed she is 'doing well' one year after being diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS).

The actress spoke to TMZ about her diagnosis and revealed she hopes to get back into acting while still battling her diagnosis as there is 'room for everyone'.

The Cruel Intentions star, 47, revealed she has been overwhelmed with the amount of support she has received from the public since revealing her diagnosis.

Interview: Selma Blair, 47, has revealed she is 'doing well' one year after being diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (pictured in October 2019)

She said: 'I'm really doing well. In public I'm just a little overstimulated so it might seem like I'm not doing that well but I can do well.

'It means so much that we all see each other and are kind. People have been very kind to me and I am so appreciative.'

On her upcoming acting work, Selma said she hopes to be working regularly again soon.

She said: 'I hope we can all see that there's room for everyone. It takes a little patience sometimes to see us all.'

Positive: The actress spoke to TMZ about her diagnosis and revealed she hopes to get back into acting while still battling her diagnosis as there is 'room for everyone'

The Storytelling star revealed her MS diagnosis publicly in October 2018, but she had experienced the symptoms for the preceding five years, according to her Vanity Fair profile from February.

For years, Selma thought she was suffering from minor illnesses or possibly a pinched nerve, and doctor's further delayed a diagnosis by attributing her symptoms to the stress of being a single mother.

Since getting her diagnosis, she's been open about her struggles getting around and raising awareness of the condition and often walks with a cane for assistance.

Two months ago Selma jetted abroad to complete a course of hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, and has documented some of the difficult side-effects with fans including the loss of her hair.

Selma said: 'I'm really doing well. In public I'm just a little overstimulated so it might seem like I'm not doing that well but I can do well'

She left her son Arthur, eight, in California to undergo the gruelling HSCT treatment.

The star revealed that the ensuing chemotherapy meant she had lost her hair, and posted a snap of her bold look after finally being discharged from hospital.

The actress has two films due out in the coming months. She will reprise her role as Carol Young in the upcoming After sequel - titled After We Collided - due out in 2020.

The 2019 romantic drama starred newcomer Josephine Langford, 22, and Hero Fiennes-Tiffin, 21, and earned $69.5 million at the worldwide box office.

Selma will also portray Dr. Doris Baxter in the crime horror film A Dark Foe currently in post-production.
